Scheme 2 Syngas production through dry reforming of ethanol over Co@SiO2 catalysts: Effect of SiO2 shell thickness Ting Li Investigation Writing – original draft 1 a Feifei Li Investigation 1 a Jessica Nginyo Writing – original draft a Weijie Cai Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Bo Yu Funding acquisition b ⁎ a Faculty of Light Industry and Chemical Engineering, Dalian Polytechnic University, Dalian 116023, China Faculty of Light Industry and Chemical Engineering Dalian Polytechnic University Dalian 116023 China aFaculty of Light Industry and Chemical Engineering, Dalian Polytechnic University, Dalian 116023, China b School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Dalian University Dalian 116622 China bSchool of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 T. Li and F.F.L contributed equally to this work. Morphology structure is regarded as one of the key factors in developing highly efficient catalysts for heterogeneous catalytic reactions. In this work, the influence of SiO2 shell thickness on the performance of the Co@SiO2 catalysts in ethanol dry reforming was studied in detail. Indeed, the different shell thickness resulted in various strengths of metal-support interactions for the Co@SiO2 catalysts, thereby greatly affecting the activity/stability. Herein, Co@SiO2–1.5 sample with ca.20 nm shell thickness exhibited better physicochemical properties. The Oads/Olatt ratio of Co@SiO2–1.5 (1.03) was higher than that of Co@SiO2–1 (0.75) and Co@SiO2–2.5 (0.91) as depicted in XPS spectra. Oads sites were indexed with the activated O species originated from O defects. On the other hand, the highest performance was obtained over Co@SiO2–1.5 sample with the optimal shell thickness as well as strong metal-support interaction. Particularly, 100% of ethanol conversion was achieved at 550 °C for Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst and the targeted H2/CO ratio was closer to 1 compared to other samples. In addition, no obvious deactivation (ethanol conversion still be 100%) occurred after 40 h time on stream tests. This finding might depict a general strategy to design/develop the attractive catalysts with the core/shell structure for other heterogeneous reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co@sio2 Core/shell structure Ethanol dry reforming Metal-support interaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Up to date, CO2 reforming with bio-ethanol (EDR) has been considered as one of the attractive approaches to recycle and convert the greenhouse gas CO2 into value-added chemicals [1,2]. Particularly, the formed syngas is suitable as feedstocks for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, an important industrial process [3–5]. Compared to the common methane dry reforming (MDR), EDR process offers the outstanding advantage: utilization of bio-ethanol coming from the renewable biomass, which might greatly meet with the sustainable development [6]. In the past few decades, MDR reaction has been widely researched over the various catalysts including transition metals and noble metals [7,8]. On the contrary, the research about EDR process is still in its infancy. With respect to the highly efficient catalyst development, great efforts have been focused on the transition metal-based catalysts with well-controlled nanostructure which present the comparative activity to noble metal-based catalysts [9]. Typically, Co-based catalysts have been regarded as an alternative considering the low cost and the satisfactory activity [10].Cao et al. deeply investigated methane dry reforming over Co/Al2O3 catalysts with various promoters such as dysprosium [11] and ceria [12]. The developed systems exhibited the good performance toward to methane dry reforming. Due to the difficulty in activating inert CO2, EDR process is a highly endothermic reaction that need the high temperature. Noticeably, high operating temperature might accelerate the formation of carbonaceous deposits which could cover the active sites and promote the aggregation of Co3O4 that greatly weaken the metal-support interaction [13]. Hence, the unsatisfactory stability caused by carbon formation and the sintering of active metal is a big problem for the Co-based catalysts. To be addressed this issue, developing the stable Co catalysts is still one of the great challenges for the ethanol dry reforming reaction. Recently, the considerable research has been conducted on the preparation of core@shell nanocomposites regarding their merits in the transportation and diffusion for catalytic reactions [14]. It has been reported that the encapsulation of Ni nanoparticles with a porous silica shell could efficiently prevent the aggregation of active metal Ni under the high reaction temperature [15]. In particular, the nanoparticles isolated inside the shells possessed a relatively uniform condition. Additionally, Somorjai et al. designed a Pt@mesoporous SiO2 catalyst with the outstanding stability even at 600 °C [16]. Zhang et al. reported that Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst significantly improved the catalytic behavior compared to Co3O4 nanowires, revealing the synergistic effect between the core and shell components [17]. In the past decades, many researchers have optimized the synthesis parameters for core@shell catalysts including preparation method, the calcination temperature and the shell porosity etc. [18–20]. However, only several groups have studied the effect of core/shell structure on catalytic performance, especially for Co-based catalysts with core@shell structure [21,22]. Seo et al. investigated the influence of the core-shell thickness on the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [23]. The results indicated that a volcano curve was observed for the H2O2 formation related with the shell thickness. In this work, the influence of SiO2 shell on the catalytic performance of Co@SiO2 for EDR reaction was studied to optimize the shell thickness. Co3O4 core nanoparticles were synthesized via solvothermal method with PVP as the capping agent. Indeed, the PVP-stabilized core nanoparticles which highly dispersed in ethanol solution could facilitate the formation of SiO2 shell. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chemicals of ethanol, Co(NO3)3·6H2O, ammonium hydroxide solution (25–28% NH3 basis), poly-(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) and tetraethylorthosilcate (TEOS) were selected without pre-treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The procedures for the synthesis of Co@SiO2 with different shell thickness were presented in Scheme 1 . 2.2.1 Preparation of Co3O4nanoparticles Typically, 0.73 g Co (NO3)3·6H2O and 0.5 g PVP were dissolved into 120 mL water under magnetic stirring to form a homogenous solution. 4 mL ammonium hydroxide solution was then added to the solution. After stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heat-treated at 140 °C for 12 h. The collected precursors were calcined at 550 °C for 3.5 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of co@sio2 Co@SiO2 catalysts were synthesized via the Stöber method. Firstly, 0.5 g of the as-prepared Co nanoparticles was dispersed in ethanol. After ultrasonication for 0.5 h, 15 g PVP was added to the solution. After reacted at room temperature for 12 h, 50 mL ammonia was poured into the solution. Subsequently, 100 mL ethanol containing diverse amounts of TEOS (1 mL, 1.5 mL, 2.5 mL) was added drop by drop. After 2.5 h reaction, the products were obtained after thoroughly washed by hot deionized water and ethanol and calcined at 550 °C for 3.5 h. According to the volume of TEOS, the obtained catalysts were labeled as Co@SiO2–1, Co@SiO2–1.5 and Co@SiO2–2.5, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Morphology structures of the catalysts were probed by a JEM-2100 (UHR) transmission electron microscope (TEM). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected using a JSM-7800F Thermal field emission scanning electron microscope. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on a ZHD-TPX-6 apparatus. 100 mg samples were loaded in a quartz tube and pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h with a N2 flow (40 mL/min). After cooling down to 50 °C, a flow of 5 vol% H2/Ar (40 mL/min) was injected and the temperature was heated to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using an X-ray diffractor (XRD-7000 s, Japan) operated at 40 KV and 30 mA with Cu-K α radiation (λ=1.5406 Å). Indeed, the 2 θ range was from 10 ∘ to 70 ∘ with the scanning speed of 10 ∘ /min. The porous structure of Co@SiO2 catalyst was investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms conducted on an ASAP 2460 equipment. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was selected to calculate the distribution of the pore size. Raman spectra were detected using a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope with a 514 nm laser as the excitation source and the laser intensity was set as 2 mW. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were conducted on a Thermo VG scientific ESCA MultiLab-2000 setup to probe the valence states and surface properties of the catalysts. 2.4 Catalytic tests Ethanol reforming with CO2 reaction was conducted at atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed reactor as shown in Scheme 2 . Particularly, 100 mg fresh catalysts (40–60 mesh) were loaded in a quartz tube and pre-reduced at 500 °C by a 5 vol% H2/N2 flow (40 mL/min). Reactant gas with a composition of C2H6O/CO2/N2=1/1/2 (molar ratio) was then introduced and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was set as 65,000 mL gcat −1h−1. The effluent gas was on-line monitored by a gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Indeed, activity tests in this work were repeated at least twice to determine the reproducibility of the experiments. Ethanol conversion and product selectivity were obtained based on the following equation: (1) X E t O H = C E t O H ( i n ) − C E t O H ( o u t ) C E t O H ( i n ) × 100 % Where C E t O H ( i n ) and C E t O H ( o u t ) related to the molar flow of ethanol in inlet and outlet gas, respectively. (2) S x * = C x ( o u t l e t ) ∑ C i ( o u t l e t ) × 100 % Where S x * corresponded to the selectivity of the product x and C i ( o u t l e t ) was the molar concentration of the product i in the outlet gas (except CO2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the as-prepared co@sio2 catalysts TEM images of the Co@SiO2 catalysts prepared with various amounts of TEOS are shown in Fig. 1 (b–d). Typically, Co3O4 nanoparticles and silica shell were clearly observed, suggesting the successful synthesis of core@shell structure catalysts. The findings revealed that nickel nanoparticles were encapsulated and/or confined by the SiO2 shell. As illustrated by Xie et al. [14], the adsorption of the capping agent PVP onto the Co3O4 nanoparticles via hydrogen bond might efficiently stabilize the Co3O4 nanoparticles, thereby inhibiting their aggregation during solvothermal process. The results implied that the addition of PVP surfactant was favorable for the preparation of Co3O4 nanoparticles. Indeed, the silicate oligomers from the hydrolyzation of TEOS could self-assemble onto the PVP-stabilized Co3O4 species, leading to the formation of SiO2 shell. With the addition of less TEOS (Co@SiO2–1), the percentage of the core@shell nanoparticles containing multiple Co3O4 nanoparticles within a single SiO2 shell was higher. On the other hand, the silica shell of Co@SiO2 catalyst became thicker from ca.16 nm (Co@SiO2–1) to ca.30 nm (Co@SiO2–2.5). This verified that the SiO2 shell thickness could be easily controlled via changing the amount of TEOS. XRD patterns of Co@SiO2 catalysts with different shell thickness are shown in Fig.2 . Herein, the peaks located at 19°, 31.2 o, 36.8 o, 38.6°, 44.8 o, 55.6 o, 59.4 o, 65.2 o for the as-prepared Co3O4 nanoparticles might be attributed to (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), (440) crystal planes of Co3O4 crystalline phase (JCPDS: 42–1467) [24,25]. This evidenced the preparation of Co3O4 nanoparticles by the solvothermal method. After coating with various thickness of SiO2 shell, XRD patterns presented the similar diffraction bands to Co3O4 nanoparticles, implying that Co3O4 phase was still maintained. In addition, the less intensity was observed for Co@SiO2–2.5 sample probably due to the blocking of the thicker shell. Fig. 3 presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the Co@SiO2 catalysts. It should be noted that the investigated samples exhibited the Type-IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop, evidencing the mesoporous structure [26,27]. In addition, the inserted pore size distribution plots in which the pore sizes were mainly within 2–4 nm, further demonstrated the presence of mesopores. Herein, the mesopores might be formed due to the thermal decomposition of the added PVP surfactant during the calcination process [28]. Besides, the multilayer adsorption property before the onset of capillary condensation was noted implying the presence of slit-shaped pores between the SiO2 nanoparticles in the shell. As depicted in the previous literature [29], this characteristic could facilitate the occurrence of gaseous exchange during the dry reforming process. Meanwhile, the specific surface area increased from 20.1 m2/g (Co@SiO2–1) to 31.0 m2/g (Co@SiO2–2.5). The pore volume slightly changed from 0.12 cm3/g (Co@SiO2–1) to 0.13 cm3/g (Co@SiO2–2.5). This finding was in line with the illustration of Lu et al. [28] that increasing the shell might also enhance the porosity and specific surface area. Particularly, H2-TPR technique could be selected to determine the reducibility of the catalyst which is regarded as one of the important factors affecting the catalytic performance. Herein, H2-TPR profiles of Co@SiO2 catalysts with different shell thickness are depicted in Fig. 4 to explore their reduction behavior. In all cases, two main H2-consumption peaks at ca.380 °C and 436 °C appeared, which corresponded to the reduction of Co3O4 nanoparticles to CoO and then to metallic Co species, respectively (Co3O4 → CoO → Co) [30]. Clearly, the protective effect of mesoporous SiO2 shell might retard the diffusion of hydrogen to reduce Co3O4 nanoparticles. Herein, it was unfavorable for hydrogen to spread along the mesoporous channels to contact with cobalt oxide nanoparticles due to the existence of silica shell. Consequently, all samples exhibited a broad reduction profile. It should be noted that the complete reduction temperature was higher for the Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst compared to another two samples. This implied the stronger interaction between Co3O4 core and SiO2 shell in Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst. It was difficult for Co3O4 nanoparticles to be reduced into metallic Co species because of the strong interaction between CoO nanoparticles and SiOH groups [14]. Moreover, the reduction of Co silicate species was not observed at above 700 °C, thereby indicating the absence of Co silicate species in the current catalysts [31]. Fig. 5 shows the Raman spectra of the investigated catalysts. Herein, the bands at ca.194, 481, 521, 617, 685 cm−1 were related to the A1g, Eg, and F2g vibration modes of Co3O4, respectively [32]. In addition, no characteristic bands attributed to silica were observed in all cased as depicted in the previous literature [33]. It should be noted that the catalysts displayed the Raman bands of Co3O4 species with the difference in the band intensity. More importantly, the band intensity decreased in the following trend: Co@Co3O4–1>Co@SiO2–1.5 >Co@SiO2–2.5, probably due to the influence of SiO2 shell thickness. XPS spectra are generally employed to determine the surface chemical states. The chemical bonding states, a key factor for the application of the core@shell nanomaterials as catalysts, were also evaluated. As presented in Fig. 6 a, the presence of Co species could be clearly observed in the wide spectra. In addition, the binding energy corresponding to Si 2p peak appeared in the region of 102 and 104 eV, which was in line with the results in the previous literature [34]. On the other hand, the Co 2p XPS spectrum was deconvoluted into six bands (Fig. 6b). Typically, the spin-orbit peaks at 782 and 797 eV were related to Co 2p3/2and Co 2p1/2, respectively, indicating the existence of Co3+ species. Additionally, the peaks at 785 and 799 eV corresponded to the Co2+species [35]. The finding revealed the existence of combination oxidation states of cobalt species. This might be due to the ex-situ reduction conditions in which metallic Co sites might be re-oxidized. It should be noted that the intensity of Co 2p spectra remarkably declined in the following order: Co@SiO2–1>Co@SiO2–1.5 >Co@SiO2–2.5. This might be caused by the thickness of SiO2 layer. Fig. 6c shows the O 1 s XPS spectra, which were broad probably because of the combined contribution of oxygen from cobalt and silica. Moreover, the spectrum was deconvoluted into two bands implying the existence of multiple O species. In particular, the band at ca.530 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (Olatt) while another band at ca.533 eV corresponded to the adsorptive or defective O species (Oads) [36,37]. These bands implied the existence of abundant oxygen sites. Indeed, Oads were considered as the activated O species originated from O defects with the lower coordination trait and/or the weaker bonding of surface O species [38], which was favorable for ethanol dry reforming at low temperatures. The Oads/Olatt value was quantified according to the areas of the two bands. The Oads/Olatt ratio of Co@SiO2–1.5 (1.03) was higher than that of Co@SiO2–1 (0.75) and Co@SiO2–2.5 (0.91) which was indexed with catalytic performance of these samples for ethanol dry reforming. On the other hand, in the case of Co@SiO2–1.5 sample, a slight shift of the O 1 s spectra was noticed compared to other samples. The result revealed some changes in the O environment for Co@SiO2–1.5 which might be due to the interaction of SiO2 and cobalt species. As elucidated by He et al. [39], upon the incorporation of guest ions into host ions, the slight electro-negativity variance between the host and guest ions could enhance the mobility of oxygen, which facilitated the migration process from internal lattice oxygen to surface oxygen. In other words, this finding probably indicated the formation of a Co-Si solid solution which was in accordance with the TPR findings. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability of ethanol dry reforming over the co@sio2 catalysts Ethanol dry reforming (EDR) performances over the investigated Co@SiO2catalysts revealed that the thickness of SiO2 shell greatly affected the reactant conversion and product selectivity. As shown in Fig. 7 , Co@SiO2–1.5 sample exhibited the highest ethanol conversion (100%) at 550 °C compared to Co@SiO2–1 (92%) and Co@SiO2–2.5 (87%). This result was higher than the value of Cu/Ce0.8Zr0.2 O2 catalyst over which complete ethanol conversion was obtained at 700 °C as reported in the previous literature [40]. Dai-Viet N. Vo et al. elucidated the relatively less activity over Ce-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst while the experimental conditions were different from this work [41]. Meanwhile, CO2 conversion also followed the similar trend: Co@SiO2–1.5 (30.7%) > Co@SiO2–1 (25%) > Co@SiO2–2.5 (17.2%). On the other hand, the targeted H2/CO ratio over Co@SiO2–1.5 (1.02) was closer to 1.0 in comparison with Co@SiO2–1 (1.13) and Co@SiO2–2.5 (2.32), which was favorable for the downstream F-T process. With respect to other byproducts, ca.6mol% acetone was formed over Co@SiO2–2.5 sample suggesting its less CC bond dissociation capacity. The strong metal support interaction in Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst as depicted in H2-TPR profiles could provide the preferrable interface structure, thereby enhancing ethanol conversion. The above results indicated that the Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst exhibited the highest EDR activity/selectivity. On the contrary, further increasing the shell thickness (Co@SiO2–2.5) resulted into the decline of the catalytic behavior. These results demonstrated the interesting findings that EDR performance greatly relied on the shell thickness in Co@SiO2 catalysts because of the relationship between the shell thickness and EDR performance. In this case, this might be explained by the strength difference of Co-Si interaction as well as the various amount of oxygen defects caused by the different shell thickness as depicted in H2-TPR and XPS analysis. The effect of reaction temperature on catalytic activity for ethanol dry reforming was probed under the stoichiometric feed ratio and a temperature region of 500 °C to 750 °C. As presented in Fig. 8 , CO formation was favorable with increasing temperature while H2 yield followed the reverse trend. On the other hand, the concentration of methane decreased at high temperature, suggesting the reaction between methane and CO2 (CH4 + CO2→CO + H2). As demonstrated by Assaf et al. [42], high temperature could enhance methane dry reforming considering its endothermic features. In addition, the influence of space velocity (GHSV) was also evaluated over Co@SiO2–1.5 sample. Upon the decline of GHSV from 65,000 mL gcat −1h−1 to 27,700 mL gcat −1h−1, the targeted H2 and CO yield increased while the concentration of methane decreased from 17.5 to 8.9. This implied the favorable occurrence of methane dry reforming under the low space velocity. Indeed, the smaller GHSV corresponded to the higher contact time, probably increasing the reaction rate of methane dry reforming. Stability test of ethanol dry reforming reaction over the Co@SiO2 catalysts were carried out with the stoichiometric feed ratios. As depicted in Fig. 9 , in all cases, ethanol conversion as well as CO2 conversion was relatively stable in the whole testing periods. In contrast, the targeted H2/CO molar ratio over the Co@SiO2–2.5 catalyst remarkably decreased at the initial 10 h and the slightly decline occurred after 35 h on stream. This might be attributed to the occurrence of the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS, H2 + CO2→ CO + H2O) in which hydrogen was consumed with the production of carbon monoxide. This finding indicated the deactivation of the Co@SiO2–2.5 sample. It should be noted that the decayed rates of Co@SiO2–1.5 was less than the others, suggesting its relatively stable performance. Moreover, it presented the comparable stability with noble metal-based catalyst (Rh/CeO2) [43] and Ni-La/Al2O3 catalyst [6]. 3.3 Characterizations of the used co@sio2 catalysts Fig. 10 shows the TEM images of the used Co@SiO2 catalysts. In case of the spent Co@SiO2–1 sample, one SiO2 nanosphere encapsulated into one Co nanoparticles. This finding was different from the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1b) in which several small Co nanoparticles were located. Hence, this result indicated the aggregation of tiny Co nanoparticles in the cavities of SiO2 nanospheres. On the other hand, the abundant amount of carbon filaments with a great variance in length and diameter were formed over the used Co@SiO2–2.5 sample (Fig. 10e,f), which resulted into the deactivation. As it was depicted, the highest deactivation rate was for Co@SiO2–2.5. On the contrary, no obvious coke deposition was noted over the used Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst with the best stability while the coating structure might also be maintained. This good stability might be caused that Co@SiO2–1.5 sample possessed the highest amount of oxygen defects as determined by Oads/Olatt ratio in XPS profiles. This positive factor could facilitate the reaction of deposited coke with reactant CO2 to retard carbon formation during the reaction process. Similarly, Fayaz et al. illustrated that CeO2 promoter in Co/Al2O3 catalyst could enhance the generation of oxygen vacancies which oxidizing coke species [44]. 3 Conclusions In summary, a series of Co@SiO2 catalysts with various SiO2 shell thickness were prepared by a facile Stöber method. The influence of shell thickness on the physicochemical properties as well as the catalytic behavior was studied in detail. Particularly, different shell thickness led to the various metal-support interaction strengths as revealed in H2-TPR and XPS findings, thereby remarkably affecting the EDR activity/stability. Indeed, the better performance as well as the higher carbon resistance capacity was achieved over Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst with strong metal-support interaction compared to other samples. For Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst, the complete ethanol conversion was achieved at 550 °C with a CO2 conversion of 31%. In addition, H2/CO ratio was near to the targeted value (1.0) which was preferable for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. More importantly, no obvious fluctuation was noted during ca.40 h stability tests. TEM images of the spent catalyst implied the less formation of carbon, probably caused by the strong metal support interaction and adequate oxygen defects. XPS spectra depicted that the activated O species originated from O vacancies in Co@SiO2–1.5 were higher in comparison with other samples. Decreasing space velocity was favorable for ethanol dry reforming. The strategy for the development of highly efficient catalyst in this work might also be suitable to other heterogeneous catalytic reactions operated with high temperature. coredata.dc:description: Morphology structure is regarded as one of the key factors in developing highly efficient catalysts for heterogeneous catalytic reactions. In this work, the influence of SiO2 shell thickness on the performance of the Co@SiO2 catalysts in ethanol dry reforming was studied in detail. Indeed, the different shell thickness resulted in various strengths of metal-support interactions for the Co@SiO2 catalysts, thereby greatly affecting the activity/stability. Herein, Co@SiO2–1.5 sample with ca.20 nm shell thickness exhibited better physicochemical properties. The Oads/Olatt ratio of Co@SiO2–1.5 (1.03) was higher than that of Co@SiO2–1 (0.75) and Co@SiO2–2.5 (0.91) as depicted in XPS spectra. Oads sites were indexed with the activated O species originated from O defects. On the other hand, the highest performance was obtained over Co@SiO2–1.5 sample with the optimal shell thickness as well as strong metal-support interaction. Particularly, 100% of ethanol conversion was achieved at 550 °C for Co@SiO2–1.5 catalyst and the targeted H2/CO ratio was closer to 1 compared to other samples. In addition, no obvious deactivation (ethanol conversion still be 100%) occurred after 40 h time on stream tests. This finding might depict a general strategy to design/develop the attractive catalysts with the core/shell structure for other heterogeneous reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Syngas production through dry reforming of ethanol over Co@SiO2 catalysts: Effect of SiO2 shell thickness
